page.title: 18The Whispering Post
page.content: The Whispering Post nowadays stands in a flower bed at Kings Hill, Rochford. It's made of wood and stands five feet high. Its top is moulded and finishes in a sharp pyramid and is supposed to represent a candle. The story behind the post starts probably in Henry III's time when the Lord of the Manor was frequently away from home and was hated by his tenants. One night when the Lord returned home unexpectedly he found his tenants "whispering" and plotting to kill him. As a penance he commanded them to assemble annually on the Wednesday after Michaelmas to do homage for their lands in a whisper and on bended knee. Anyone absent when his name was called had to pay a heavy fine. This tradition continued until 1892 but was revived by The Rochford Hundred Historical Society who now re-enact it annually at Rochford Hall.
